journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Engine performance and exhaust emissions in stoichiometric combustion engines fuelled with dimethyl ether

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate School of Hanyang University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Seongdong-gu, Seoul, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, 17 Haengdang-dong, Seongdong-gu, Seoul 133791, Republic of Korea. email: parks@hanyang.ac.kr

abstract.p: This paper describes the effects of stoichiometric combustion on the engine performance and exhaust emissions in a single-cylinder compression ignition engine fuelled with dimethyl ether. In order to realize stoichiometric combustion in a direct-injection compression ignition engine, high exhaust gas recirculation was used to control air-to-fuel ratios based on a lambda meter. The combustion pressure, heat release rate, and indicated mean effective pressure, which are the main indicators of the engine performance, were derived from in-cylinder pressure data in a single-cylinder direct-injection compression ignition engine. The test engine had a displacement volume of 373.3 cm3, a compression ratio of 17.8, and a common-rail injection system. Exhaust emissions characteristics were obtained from emission gas analysers at the tailpipe.

The experimental results show that increasing the equivalence ratio dramatically reduced the indicated specific nitrogen oxide emissions (i.e. by over 90 per cent) owing to the high exhaust gas recirculation in the conventional diesel combustion regime. Furthermore, soot emissions were negligible owing to the chemical properties of the dimethyl ether fuel in the operation range of the injection timings. For injection timings near top dead centre, the indicated specific carbon monoxide emission levels rise excessively as the equivalence ratio increases and the maximum value is 80.9 g/kW h. However, for advanced injection timing (i.e. near 25° crank angle before top dead centre), the indicated specific carbon monoxide emission level shows minimal variation as the equivalence ratio changes. In contrast, the levels of indicated specific hydrocarbon emissions vary according to the injection timing. Increasing the equivalence ratio causes the indicated mean effective pressure to deteriorate slightly (i.e. up to 10 per cent loss) owing to the intake conditions for high exhaust gas recirculation, which results in a low oxygen concentration and a high carbon dioxide concentration.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Recently, in order to meet strict emission regulations while improving the fuel consumption, many research groups have also suggested advanced combustion strategies including homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) [1, 2], premixed charge compression ignition (PCCI) [3, 4], low-temperature combustion [5], dual-fuel combustion [6, 7], and stoichiometric combustion [8, 9]. All these combustion strategies use the same key technique: controlling the air–fuel mixture charge distributed in the combustion chamber. Among these combustion strategies, stoichiometric combustion utilizes a three-way catalyst in order to reduce exhaust emissions in compression ignition (CI) engines. Therefore, the most important goals are to avoid unnecessary fuel consumption and to reduce soot emissions compared with those in conventional diesel combustion [10].

Dimethyl ether (DME) is a promising alternative fuel with merits for use in CI engines. In terms of its molecular structure, DME has no direct carbon–carbon (C–C) bonds because an oxygen atom is located between the two molecules of methyl ether (CH3), as listed in Table 1. This chemical characteristic can significantly suppress the formation and development of soot emissions in a CI regime. In addition, DME leads to a shorter ignition delay owing to its high cetane number and lowers in-cylinder temperatures owing to its high latent heat. DME also has a good atomization characteristic because of its low boiling point and its gas phase in the atmosphere [11, 12]. Among these merits, therefore, the present study is focused on the zero-level soot emission characteristic as an improvement in the high level of soot emissions associated with diesel stoichiometric combustion, which leads to the selection of DME fuel for stoichiometric combustion. Huang et al. [13] and Wang et al. [14] analysed combustion and emissions characteristics for a light-duty CI engine fuelled with DME. They reported that DME has a shorter ignition delay than that of diesel in spite of a longer injection delay and duration. Also, it has a low pressure rise rate and smokeless combustion. In addition, Teng and McCandless [15] reported that DME could possibly reduce nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions for the low- and the high-load operation regions in a heavy-duty CI engine with a multiple-injection strategy and high exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) rate. Yoon et al. [16] experimentally investigated the effects of a pilot injection strategy on EGR combustion characteristics for a DME engine. They revealed that the pilot injection decreased EGR of hydrocarbons (HCs), carbon monoxide (CO), and particulate matter emissions but increased NOx emissions owing to activation of the EGR main combustion regime by EGR pilot injection. In another study with a rich equivalence ratio and HCCI combustion with applied fuel reactivity in a DME engine, Egnell [17] reported that NOx formation was suppressed at higher equivalence ratios because of the lower local oxygen concentration. In addition, Shudo et al. [18] reported that both hydrogen and CO retarded the start of the second-stage combustion regime in an HCCI DME engine.

caption.p: Properties of the DME fuel

sec.p: To achieve stoichiometric combustion using DME fuel, it is important to consider how various equivalence ratios affect the combustion and exhaust emissions characteristics. Therefore, the present study investigates using a single-cylinder CI engine in a high-EGR DME fuel injection system. Moreover, the injection timing is swept from 3° crank angle (CA) after top dead centre (ATDC) to 40° CA before top dead centre (BTDC) in order to compare with conventional diesel combustion and PCCI regimes.

sec.title: 2.1 Experimental set-up
sec.p: The experimental system consisted of a test engine and exhaust emissions measurements, as illustrated in Fig. 1. The test engine was based on a single-cylinder common-rail direct-injection system with a displacement volume of 373.3 cm3, a compression ratio of 17.8, and a re-entrant type of piston-bowl shape. The injector had six holes and a 156° spray angle. Detailed specifications of the test engine system are given in Table 2. The engine speed was controlled with a d.c. dynamometer (5 kW) system. The amount of injected fuel was controlled using an injector driver (TEMS TDA-3300). In addition, the top dead centre (TDC) was determined and the injection timing was controlled using a timing pulse generator (Blue Planet TPG-28 MP), which were synchronized with two signals, from the crank and the camshaft angle sensor. A piezoelectric transducer (Kistler 6057A80) was mounted on a cylinder head instead of a glow-plug in order to acquire the in-cylinder pressure data. The acquired signal was thereafter amplified using a charge amplifier (Kistler 5011B) and stored using a data acquisition board (National Instruments PCI-MIO-16E-1). In each case, the in-cylinder pressure histories were measured for 150 cycles and were used to calculate the engine performance indicators, such as the indicated mean effective pressure (IMEP), the heat release rate (HRR), and the start of combustion (SOC).

caption.p: Schematic diagram of a single-cylinder direct-injection diesel engine
Specifications of test engine and direct injector

fn.p: DI, direct injection; DOHC, double overhead camshaft; CA, crank angle; BTDC, before top dead centre; ABDC, after bottom dead centre; BBDC, before bottom dead centre; ATDC, after top dead centre.

sec.p: To maintain a constant flowrate, the intake air was controlled and monitored with a mass flow controller (Aalborg GFC-67). In order to bring the DME to stoichiometric combustion, an EGR system was constructed and a premixing chamber was mounted to mix intake air with sufficiently recirculated exhaust emission gas. In addition, to measure the equivalence ratio, a lambda meter (ETAS LA4) was mounted on the exhaust manifold.

The exhaust emissions measurements consisted of a smoke meter (AVL 415S) and an exhaust gas analyser (Horiba MEXA-554 JK) which measured raw exhaust gas without after-treatment at the tailpipe, as shown in Fig. 1. In all cases, exhaust emissions were measured when the engine condition was in a steady state after a sufficiently long stabilizing operating time. Soot was measured using a smoke meter with a filter smoke number unit using a method measuring the loss of the reflectivity of the filter paper. Other exhaust gases such as NOx, HC, and CO were measured with an exhaust gas analyser [19]. This measurement used the principle of non-dispersive infrared rays and has accuracies of ± 1.0 vol % for NOx, ± 12 vol ppm for HC, and ± 0.06 vol % for CO.

sec.title: 2.2 Operating conditions
sec.p: The objective of the present study is to analyse the characteristics of combustion and exhaust emissions for DME stoichiometric combustion. In order to increase the equivalence ratio, a high-EGR system was applied to the intake and exhaust system, as shown in Fig. 1. The EGR system consisted of a settling chamber, an EGR cooler, a premixing chamber, an EGR valve, and a back-pressure control valve. The definition of the EGR ratio used in this study is

where

is the mass flowrate of the recycled exhaust gas and is defined as the difference between
m

m
·
air
, where
m
·
i
is the mass flowrate of the total mixture into the combustion chamber and
m
·
air
is the mass flowrate of air.

In order to keep the operating equivalence ratio constant, its value was accurately measured with a lambda meter, which was mounted on the exhaust manifold. The principle of the EGR system is that the recycled exhaust gas is driven by the pressure difference between the settling chamber of the exhaust gas and the premixing chamber of the intake air. In addition, the intake air mass was controlled using the airflow controller (see Fig. 1).

The present study investigates the effects of various equivalence ratios and, eventually, stoichiometric combustion. Thus, the injected amount of DME is fixed at 23 mg per unit cycle (i.e. Φ = 0.6 without EGR) in order to keep a constant low heating value (LHV) in the combustion chamber. Detailed operating conditions are listed in Table 3.

caption.p: Operating conditions

fn.p: EGR, exhaust gas recirculation; CA, crank angle; ATDC, after top dead centre.

sec.p: In the present study, the SOC is defined as the crank angle at 10 per cent heat release in terms of total heat release (denoted CA10). The ignition delay is defined as the CA between the start of injection (SOI) and the SOC.

The following operating conditions were fixed: an engine speed of 1200 r/min, a total inlet mass flowrate of 12.3 kg/h, and an intake temperature of 320 ± 5 K. The detailed conditions and injection strategies are listed in Table 3.

sec.title: 3.1 Effects of stoichiometric DME combustion
sec.p: The EGR technique is a significant way to suppress NOx formation because its dilution, thermal, and chemical effects lower the flame temperature of CI. Moreover, it is one of the most effective methods for reducing the oxygen concentration in a combustion chamber. However, high EGR can cause the loss of engine power, such as the mean effective pressure and the specific fuel consumption [20].

In the present study, to achieve stoichiometric combustion, high EGR was applied. Considering the increase in equivalence ratio caused by the high EGR, therefore it is important to determine the loss in the IMEP [21].

Figure 2 shows how the maximum IMEP for each equivalence ratio was normalized by the highest IMEP (i.e. 0.684 MPa) based on the 0.7 equivalence ratio and the SOI at TDC. This result demonstrates that the maximum IMEP slightly decreased when the equivalence ratio was richer. In particular, in the case of a 1.1 equivalence ratio, the maximum IMEP has around 17 per cent loss compared with the best possible IMEP. However, a maximum IMEP of 1.0 equivalence ratio (i.e. stoichiometric combustion) has around a 10 per cent loss. This result shows that stoichiometric combustion need not result in extreme deterioration of the engine performance.

caption.p: Normalized IMEPs for equivalence ratios. The maximum IMEPs for each equivalence ratio were normalized by the highest IMEP

sec.p: The trends of the IMEP for each case (i.e. equivalence ratios of 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) generally decrease while injection timings are advanced from TDC, as shown in Fig. 3. For this reason, the test engine system was optimized with the injection timing near TDC because the piston-bowl shape is re-entrant and the spray angle is 156°. The trends of IMEP for the 0.6 and 0.8 equivalence ratios were similar for the SOI near TDC (i.e. the TDC is at approximately 10 ° CA BTDC); however, the case of the 0.8 equivalence ratio was applied to EGR (i.e. EGR of 24 per cent). Furthermore, the IMEPs for stoichiometric combustion are relatively low compared with the IMEPs for a lower equivalence ratio. However, in more advanced injection timings from near TDC (i.e. 20 – 40° CA BTDC), the values of the IMEP are reversed in the order from richer equivalence ratios to poorer equivalence ratios.

caption.p: Effect of the SOI timing on the IMEP for various equivalence ratios

sec.p: Figure 4 shows the effects of the equivalence ratio and injection timing on the ignition delay. It is seen that the ignition delay is longer for advanced injection timings. In particular, for stoichiometric combustion, the ignition delay is longer than 15° CA for an injection timing of −30° CA. Thus, it is believed that the combustion regimes of stoichiometric DME combustion (i.e. Φ = 1.0) for the advanced injection timing (i.e. from 20° CA to 30° CA BTDC) approach the PCCI regime.

caption.p: Effect of the equivalence ratio on the ignition delay

sec.p: In the case of the injection timing near TDC, the maximum cylinder pressure and the overall trends of pressure are lower for richer equivalence ratios, as shown in Fig. 5. Both the premixed combustion phase and the mixing-controlled combustion phase are clearly developed when greater injected quantities (i.e. 23 mg/cycle) and a conventional injection timing are used, as shown in Fig. 6 for the case of a 0.6 equivalence ratio without EGR. For equivalence ratios of 0.8 and 1.0, the increasing amount of EGR leads to an extended ignition delay and a shortened combustion duration. Therefore, the premixed combustion phase is more active but the mixing-controlled combustion phase rapidly disappears since the DME fuel has superior evaporation and since a longer ignition delay allows sufficient mixing time for the air–fuel mixture in the combustion chamber. Further, ignition occurs during the retarded expansion stroke, which has a relatively low in-cylinder pressure and temperature. This is the reason why the combustion pressure is low. The results show that the IMEP for a rich equivalence ratio finally decreases at an injection timing near TDC.

caption.p: Effect of the equivalence ratio on the cylinder pressure in the PCCI and conventional diesel combustion regimes
Effect of the equivalence ratio on the HRR in the PCCI and conventional diesel combustion regimes

sec.p: In advanced injection timings from TDC, on the other hand, the equivalence ratio has little effect on the overall trends of the pressure, the maximum cylinder pressure, or the HRR (i.e. almost 110 J per unit degree) during the expansion stroke; however, the SOC is clearly retarded owing to the longer ignition delay from an increasing equivalence ratio (see Figs 4, 5, and 6). Because the work related to the cylinder pressure during the compression stroke has a negative value, therefore the retarded SOC case has a higher IMEP owing to low pumping losses. Specifically, maintaining a high level of cylinder pressure during the expansion stroke greatly affects the high IMEP value because a retarded expansion stoke is associated with high values of the volume rate dV/dθ. For this reason, the IMEP values with an injection timing near TDC are high compared with those with advanced injection timing.

Figure 7 shows the effect of the equivalence ratio on the relationship between the indicated specific nitrogen oxide (ISNOx) level and the injection timing. As the equivalence ratio approaches the stoichiometry condition, the ISNOx level is significantly reduced and is at a near-zero level throughout the overall injection timing owing to high EGR.

caption.p: Effect of the equivalence ratio on the ISNOx level

sec.p: The effect of the equivalence ratio on the indicated specific soot (ISsoot) characteristics versus the injection timing is shown in Fig. 8. The ISsoot is at a near-zero level for all equivalence ratios and injection timings. In its molecular structure, DME fuel has an oxygen atom located between two methyl radicals (CH3). Therefore, DME fuel has no direct C–C bonds and this chemical characteristic can reasonably suppress soot formation [22].

caption.p: Effect of the equivalence ratio on the ISsoot level

sec.p: Figure 9 shows the effect of the equivalence ratio on the indicated specific hydrocarbon (ISHC) characteristics versus the injection timing. The trends of the ISHC for all cases vary somewhat and the ISHC sharply increases as the injection timing is advanced. Specifically, the ISHC for SOIs before 25° CA BTDC is high. At these SOIs, the DME spray collides with the cylinder liner owing to the early injection timing and the much lower cylinder pressure, and spray wall wetting occurs. As a result, the ISHC emission increases at further advanced injection timings (i.e. before 25° CA BTDC).

caption.p: Effect of the equivalence ratio on the ISHC level

sec.p: Figure 10 shows the effect of the equivalence ratio on the relationship between the indicated specific carbon monoxide (ISCO) and the injection timing. The trends of the ISCO for the 0.6 and 0.8 equivalence ratios are similar. Also, the trend for stoichiometric combustion is similar to other cases in advanced injection timing; however, the ISCO significantly increases in the region of injection timings near TDC. In this region, the high ISCO emission contains a large energy loss due to unburned products. Park and Reitz [23] reported that the CO emission suddenly rose as the equivalence ratio became richer than stoichiometric. This is the reason why there is insufficient oxygen to react with CO to give carbon dioxide (CO2), the CO remaining until the opening timing of the exhaust valve. Consequently, stoichiometric combustion with conventional injection timing has a low IMEP compared with those of other lean combustion regimes (see Fig. 3). In particular, when the DME spray is injected at around 25° CA BTDC, the ISCO is dramatically reduced, perhaps because the split DME spray can use more oxygen from both the crevice volume and the piston bowl, since the spray targeting point is the piston lip at that time [24].

caption.p: Effect of the equivalence ratio on the ISCO level

sec.title: 3.2 Effects of the extended ignition delay on stoichiometric DME combustion
sec.p: In previous results from the conventional diesel combustion regime, the stoichiometric combustion has resulted in high CO emissions and relatively low IMEP values. Hence, the ignition delay was lengthened in order to retard the combustion phase. The present study investigated the effects of a more extended ignition delay on stoichiometric DME combustion. Therefore, the physical chemistry characteristics of the test fuel were changed. The properties of ethanol fuel are very close to those of DME fuel. Ethanol and DME have the same stoichiometric air-to-fuel ratios, and the LHV of ethanol is similar to that of DME, as shown in Table 4. However, the cetane number of ethanol (i.e. less than 15) is extremely low; hence ethanol fuel is selected as an additive. The test fuels were of two types: DME with 10 wt % and 20 wt % added ethanol respectively, i.e. the amount of ethanol added was based on the mass fraction.

caption.p: Properties of the ethanol fuel

sec.p: The added ethanol increases the ignition delay in stoichiometric DME combustion, as shown in Fig. 11. The increase in the amount of ethanol significantly extends the ignition delay owing to its low cetane number and high latent heat of vaporization [25]. In particular, combustion of the added ethanol fuel occurred in the PCCI regime for the whole injection timing because of the much extended ignition delay. As a result, the IMEPs of the added ethanol cases slightly increase when ignition occurs near TDC, or ATDC, because of the retarded SOC and an active premixed combustion phase (Figs 12 and 13). In particular, the IMEP value in this case (i.e. DME + 10 wt % ethanol and SOI at 3° CA BTDC) is 0.627 MPa, which reaches almost 92 per cent of the best possible IMEP (0.684 MPa).

caption.p: Effect of the added ethanol fuel on the ignition delay in stoichiometric combustion
Effect of the added ethanol fuel on the IMEP in stoichiometric combustion
Effect of the added ethanol fuel on the HRR in stoichiometric combustion

sec.p: The CA50, shown in Fig. 14, indicates the time of most active combustion, which is near the time of the maximum cylinder pressure. Hence, CA10 – CA50 is defined as the CA, or the duration, between the SOC and CA50. The short CA10 – CA50 duration also indicates that premixed combustion occurs rapidly [26]. Therefore, this indicates the index that demonstrates the strength level of the premixed combustion regime. The premixed combustion phase actively occurs owing to the lengthened ignition delay caused by the increased ratio of ethanol.

caption.p: Effect of the added ethanol fuel on the CA10–CA50 in stoichiometric combustion

sec.p: Figures 15 and 16 show the effects of the ethanol ratio on the exhaust emissions characteristics. In the PCCI regime, the ISNOx level slightly increases because a longer ignition delay leads to activation of the premixed combustion phase, as shown by the HRR trends (see Fig. 13). In addition, Figs 11 and 13 show that the SOC occurs near TDC during the compression stroke and the peak of HRR sharply increases in the PCCI regme. Therefore, these effects also lead to a slightly increased ISNOx level in the PCCI regime. However, the increased amount of ISNOx is also very small compared with previous results on the amount of ISNOx for various equivalence ratios (see Fig. 7). For these results, the ISNOx, ISsoot, and ISHC levels have little effect considering the increase in the ethanol ratio. The ISCO of ethanol-containing cases dramatically decreases for an injection timing near TDC, as shown in Fig. 16. In the case of DME + 10 wt % ethanol with an SOI at 3° CA TDC, the reduction in the amount of ISCO is almost 52 per cent in the same SOI conditions. It is also suggested that the more active premixed combustion regime reduced the ISNOx level. It is hypothesized that the rapidly released combustion heat due to the lengthened ignition delay can be attributed to oxidized CO.

caption.p: Effect of the added ethanol fuel on the emissions (ISNOx, ISsoot, and ISHC) characteristics in stoichiometric combustion
Effect of the added ethanol fuel on the ISCO level in stoichiometric combustion

sec.title: 4 Conclusions
sec.p: In the present study, experiments were performed at various equivalence ratios, eventually resulting in stoichiometric combustion, in order to analyse the engine performance and the exhaust emissions characteristics. The following conclusions were drawn.

list-item.p: The normalized maximum IMEP slightly decreased as the equivalence ratio was richer. In particular, for an equivalence ratio of 1.1, the maximum IMEP suffered around 17 per cent loss compared with the best possible IMEP; however, the maximum IMEP of stoichiometric combustion had about 10 per cent loss.

As the injection timing advanced from the TDC, all the IMEP trends generally decreased. For the injection timing near TDC, the maximum cylinder pressure and the overall trends of pressure were reduced under richer equivalence ratios. In the advanced injection timing from TDC, the equivalence ratio had little effect on either the overall trends of the pressure or the maximum cylinder pressure during the expansion stroke; however, the SOC was clearly retarded by a longer ignition delay owing to the increased equivalence ratio.

As the equivalence ratio approached the stoichiometry condition, the ISNOx level was significantly reduced and was at near-zero level for any injection timing owing to the high EGR. Also the ISsoot emission was at near-zero level for any equivalence ratio and any injection timing because of the chemical characteristics of the DME fuel; its lack of direct C–C bonds suppresses soot formation.

All the trends of the ISCO level were similar to those of the advanced injection timing cases; however, significantly, the level of ISCO was very high in the injection timing near TDC. As early injection timing was advanced, there was little difference in the trends of the ISHC level in any case and ISHC emissions sharply increased. Specifically, the ISHC value for the SOI at 25° CA TDC was high because of the spray-wall-wetting phenomenon.

The IMEPs of the added-ethanol cases slightly increase when ignition occurs near TDC owing to the retarded SOC and an active premixed combustion phase. In addition, the ISNOx, ISsoot, and ISHC emissions have little effect considering the increased ratios of ethanol which they contain. However, the ISCO level dramatically decreases for an injection timing near TDC.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: ATDC after top dead centre
BTDC before top dead centre
EGR exhaust gas recirculation
HCCI homogeneous charge compression ignition
HRR heat release rate
IMEP indicated mean effective pressure
ISCO indicated specific carbon monoxide
ISHC indicated specific hydrocarbon
ISNOx indicated specific nitrogen oxides
ISsoot indicated specific soot
LHV lower heating value
PCCI premixed charge compression ignition
SOC start of combustion
SOI start of ignition
